Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
I'm going to send them a message and let them know.

Where do you think the error is in this workflow?

Is this a normal practice for distros of Ubuntu to exclude these libraries, so any distro would have this issue? Or is this something unique to Pop OS itself?

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Can we add gcc-7 and g++-7 to the libraries that should be installed, in the docs.komodoplatform.com documentation on installing manually?

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: they are using updated gcc version. komodo source doesn't use gcc 8

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
I'm not very familiar with gcc. 

is this something that we should change in the docs? Or is it something that I should let Pop know is causing issues? Or is it that the Komodo developer workflow hasn't updated to gcc 8 yet, but may at some point in the future?

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: https://askubuntu.com/questions/1028601/install-gcc-8-only-on-ubuntu-18-04

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: @Bryan_Beus the gcc8 comes as default with Ubuntu 18.10. popOS got it that way. you need to install gcc7 to run komodo for now.

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: it may be updated in the future

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: It looks like installing `build-essential` should add gcc-7 into the libraries?

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I see that build-essential is already in our preset commands...

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I'm trying to figure out where the issue is, to make sure that we don't have customers who have the same issue.

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: ubuntu 18.10 released recently and not a lot devs/users are using it

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: ok

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: ubuntu 16.04 still has support and most of notary nodes and other infrastructure are running on it. some of us using 18.04 which is also LTS and doesn't have this issue

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: the next logical version to update to would be 20.04 for us from 18.04

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
I'm reading this right now.

https://www.ubuntu.com/about/release-cycle

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: any odd version is test version and any x.10 is test version with short lifecycle

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: x.04 gets 5 year support

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
gotcha,

Okay, I see now.

So, it seems that it's the 18.10 aspect that's the issue, and it has less to do with Pop itself.

I believe that have an 18.04 version, and that probably should be listed as the default download on their homepage.

On my own time, I will try to roll back my system to 18.04, and I will send Pop a message letting them know about what happened.

Thanks.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: This was all very helpful. I appreciate you taking the time to work through it with me.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Can we add a note somewhere in the docs about this?

Content:
Could we put it in the docs.komodoplatform.com 

https://docs.komodoplatform.com/komodo/install-Komodo-manually.html

I would suggest putting this in the section title Linux

```
For Ubuntu, we recommend only using Ubuntu 16.04 or 18.04
```

Content: yes

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Okay, if I have access to the docs.komodoplatform.com stuff, I can put that in there now, assuming you're okay with it.

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: you can always submit a PR if you don't have direct access

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: you have write access to that repo

Content: ok, I'm doing it now

Content:
and komodod is finally running on my machine.

Thank you!

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
@SHossain 

I spoke with the developers for the Pop_OS distro, and told them about what happened. (gcc-7 not being installed by default, and only gcc-8, and that causing issues when compiling from source.)

I also told them that you suggested that I only use 18.04, since it's LTS and 18.10 is not.

They responded that when running Ubuntu on server technology you want to stay with an LTS version, when you are working with desktop users you do not. 

In the past, when distro developers let their users get behind the latest release of Ubuntu, this ends up causing more issues long-term, as they get stuck on previous releases (16.04, 14.04), and they can't upgrade to the latest release in any timely fashion.

It becomes a trap that keeps open-source projects from being able to progress.

So, they're keeping 18.10 as the default download, and they also plan to push everyone to 19.04 (and 19.10) within six months of the release dates.

FYI. I don't make any opinion myself, and I am happy to roll back to 18.04 myself for my komodo-related machines. Will do it whenever I can find the time. 

@jl777c @ca333 You might also find this interesting ^

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: @Bryan_Beus Komodo source been updated and you can compile with gcc8 now

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: great, thanks

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: @REX the reward  claim function may not be activated yet on magnum wallet. you need to get in touch with magnum team for more info.

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: @REX the reward claiming function isn't working on Magnum. They are waiting on a Ledger update that will bring back the ability to claim interest with the hardware wallet. For now, you can send and receive from Magnum.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @PTYX is it setting nlocktime properly for sends?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: you should probably clarify that if the user ever sent KMD from the ledger wallet using ledger software, the change output immediately stopped accruing rewards

Author: Alright#0419
Content: their software doesn't set nlocktime properly

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: If the send transaction set the nlocktime then claim interest would work.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @PTYX yes I'm asking if Magnum is currently setting it

Author: Alright#0419
Content: if not, as soon as user sends KMD using it, the change stops accruing rewards

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: Sorry lost connection

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: I agree, I'll make sure I let people know that if they send the nlocktime isn't set
